noun.description: Continuous physical force exerted on or against an object by something in contact with it.
examples: the slight extra pressure he applied to her hand

noun.description: The use of persuasion, influence, or intimidation to make someone do something.
examples: the many pressures on girls to worry about their looks
the proposals put pressure on Britain to drop its demand

verb.description: Attempt to persuade or coerce (someone) into doing something.
examples: it might now be possible to pressure him into resigning
she pressured her son to accept a job offer from the bank

origin: Late Middle English: from Old French, from Latin pressura, from press- pressed, from the verb premere (see press).
